I can't help whether he's painting or not, marm. The question is whether he is paying or not.
Man, my husband cannot be disturbed. Don't you see?--he is inspired.
Now for it. (_At window_.) One--two--three--I don't like the look of that glass-house much.
I must come in, marm--out of the way if _you_ please.
(_Jumps out. A tremendous crash of broken glass is heard_.)

What's that? (_Aside_.) Oh, there he is. (_Aloud_.) Here you Mr. Tempenny, sir, I've a warrant 'ere on a judgment summons.--Suit of Cole the butcher. (_Addressing lay-figure_.) Do you pay up, or come along o' me?
Which is it, sir? I allus likes to do business pleasant, only you must make up your mind, you know. Pay up, or lock up--take your choice.
(_At window. Excitedly aside_.) He disappears--he's lost to view--the danger's past.

Well, if you _won't_ speak, you _won't_, of course! I've done my 'umble best to do my dooty affable, and since you're sulky, why--(_Going up to lay-figure_) Mr. Rembrandt Tempenny, I've a warrant for your arrest.
(_He slaps the lay-figure on the shoulder, it collapses with a crash_).
(MRS. TEMPENNY _runs to_ D.F. _as if to go_. ROSALINE _half opens_ R.D. _and pops her head out with an ejaculation_.)
SCENE:--SYLVESTER'S _Studio_. (_The next day_.) _Doors R. and L. At back cupboard_. TEMPENNY _discovered painting_, ROSALINE _posed_.
Wait a minute, and you shall rest. There! now you can move if you like.
Ah, that shows your profound ignorance of the School. It promises to be a superb example. (_Contemplates it sideways_.) Exquisite!
Didn't you say this studio belonged to a friend of yours?
Oh yes; he hasn't come yet. I expect he will be here this afternoon.
What's this? (_picking up Mandarin's Wig_.) One of his props?

That? That is a Mandarin's wig. Yes, of course it is one of his props. He has just been engaged on a great work: "The Decapitation of a Mandarin after a Chinese Reverse." The gentleman who sat for the Mandarin wore that wig.
Rather playful, isn't it? He likes 'em like that. That's his forte.
Charlie Sylvester; and a rattling good chap he is, let me tell you.
I beg your pardon? Don't go off like that. What's the matter?
It is _He_--_He_ who--! Oh, I am going to faint.
No,--no, for goodness' sake, don't do that. What do you mean by "he?" Here, I say, compose yourself.
It is the man I love. The finger of Fate is in it. Where is he? Bring him to me! Charlie, my own!

Oh I say--look here, you know--? (_Aside_.) This is the devil and all--Charlie will never forgive me! (_Aloud_.) My dear good girl, he _isn't_ your "own," I assure you he isn't. There is a Mrs. Sylvester, as you know very well. (_Aside_.) If he comes in and finds her here, there's an end of all my sittings. What a piece of infernal luck to be sure!
Bring him to me--now, this instant! We have been divided too long already.
I must humour her. (_Aloud_.) Well, perhaps you _have_, on second thoughts. Yes, it is a long time.
I have never forgotten him. I have always treasured his memory in my soul.
That was very nice of you. You are a very nice girl--I saw it at once.
_He_ used to say that--he used to call me his "Toppett."

His little "Toppett?" It is a pretty name, and I am sure he will be delighted to find you here, when he comes. It will be a surprise for him, won't it; quite a surprise! (_Aside_.) A perfect devil of a surprise!
For all he knows I might be dead--dead with the violets blooming over my tomb.

Yes, yes,--buttercups and daisies. (_Aside_.) I shall get the giddy push from here when he does come; I see it sticking out a foot. (_Aloud_.) I say, Poppett--I mean "Rosaline," do you feel equal to going on with the sitting till he arrives?
It is doubtful whether Sylvester will see it in the same light. (_Aloud_.) Well, then, suppose you take up your position again.
(_He poses her with much difficulty, as each time he places her arms in the required attitude, she moves to wipe away a tear_).
There, now we've got it at last. (_He goes back to the easel, and commences to work_).
Oh, great Jupiter! This is too much! Can't you contain your emotion? I know it is very praiseworthy, but can't you bottle it up? How on earth am I to paint you while you keep going on like this.
He! (_She clasps her hands and listens_.) My heart tells me so!
It _ain't_ he--because he never rings. So your heart's told you a lie.
Mr. Sylvester--is he in? Not in? What do you mean?
No, it is the same one--do you think he is the Grand Mogul?--but she will be enough for _you_ if she finds you here, and for _me_ too!
I do not fear her. I am doing no harm--I am your Model, brought here by you.

Now look here, you know, don't say that; I won't be mixed up in it! I tell you I'll have nothing to do with the matter! I didn't know who you were, or I wouldn't have brought you within a hundred miles of the place. Hark.
I will wait in his studio till he comes. He ought to have been here long ago.
_Ought_ he! I won't be seen here--I can't. She is a friend of my wife's. I won't be found in your company. I'm a moral man, and she knows you.
Here, hi, I will be a lay-figure. By George, I've got it--I will be the Mandarin, see!
(_He disguises himself with Rosaline's assistance as a Mandarin, and sits cross-legged at back, wagging his head_.)
I don't know what you mean. Sh! Here she is.
Can I be deceived? Is it possible you are the--ahem--the person I take you for?
I really don't know who you take me for. My name is Rosaline, and I'm a model.
I knew it! How dare you come here--how dare you? Two years ago I forbade you ever to enter my husband's studio again.
I did not know it was your husband's studio when I came. I am here to sit to a friend of his.
Now let me quite understand you. Do you mean to say that it was not Mr. Sylvester who brought you here?
I did not say "Mr. Brown." A gentleman engaged me to sit to him, and told me to come here this morning at ten o'clock. He said he was a friend of Mr. Sylvester's.
Then you did know that this was Mr. Sylvester's studio!
I did not. He said it belonged to a friend of his, but did not mention his name.
Who was this friend, girl? Who told you to come? Answer me.
Oh, that is very easy. I was engaged by Mr.--
I do not know any Mr. Smith. Where has he gone?
Certainly not. I have no reason to mind telling the truth. I am naturally a truthful girl. His name was--
Once and for all--will you tell me the man's name?
You will either make a clean breast of it, or I shall take steps--
Let her take steps--that's what I want her to do.
Ah, wait--doubtless my husband is in hiding. I will see.
What do you mean by getting me into all this trouble? What do you mean by it?
This is a dignified position for a husband and a ratepayer!--the butt of a bad girl!

Your frivolity will avail you nothing. If you were indeed brought here by a friend of Mr. Sylvester's, I can guess who he is. His name is Tempenny, and I shall enquire into the matter at once. (_Going_.)
I am nobody's accomplice--I am an honest woman earning a living. I will tell lies for no one.
Oh, this is infamous! So Mr. Tempenny assists my husband to deceive me, does he? We will see what his wife has to say to it. Birds of a feather--as I always thought. Abandoned wretches both!
Don't you talk to me like that--I won't have it!
And I'll smack it again if you aggravate me. If it weren't that _he_ will be here later on, I'd walk straight out of the studio, and never come into it again.

I've a good mind to bundle you out neck and crop, I can tell you. That woman has gone off to complain to my wife. Here, get me out of these things. (_He divests himself of the Chinese wig and costume_.) I think I had better go. I don't know how I'll do the picture--I'll _never_ do the picture. I think _you_ had better go--if Charlie Sylvester finds you here after this, he will murder you.
He! Oh, I say, you know--don't yer know--this is awful!
Yes, so do I! He'll kill you--I warn you he will make a corse of you--or _me_. I won't meet him. I can't. Get rid of him for the Lord's sake--I'll hide in there till he has gone.
Great Scott! My dear girl, what on earth are you here for?
"Greet" you? Well, upon my word I don't quite know what you expect. I thought it was understood between us last time we met that--that--we weren't to meet? You see I've got a wife, and--
What's that you say? You have just seen my wife?
The devil! What did she say to you--what did she think?
And very rightly too. You have no business here--why did you come?
What? Are _you_ his model? This is really too bad. Where is he?
What for? (_Calling_.) Tempenny! I say, Tempenny, I want you!
Ah--er--good morning, dear boy. What weather, eh? What weather we're having to be sure. (_Aside to_ ROSALINE.) You malicious, base-hearted--(_Shakes his fist at her_.) Oh!
Look here, you know, Tempenny, this won't do. You have no right to bring the girl here. I don't think it was at all friendly of you. I--I consider it a damned liberty of you in fact.
I was afraid you would be vexed, but don't be cross, dear old man; don't be "put out" about it. (_Trying to laugh_.) There are worse troubles at sea, as they say--worse troubles at sea!

(_With rising indignation_.) But I _am_ put out. Damn the sea--what's that got to do with it. Mrs. Sylvester has been in and seen her, I understand? You have served me a very shabby trick, Tempenny--I am very sorry about it!
(_Still trying to laugh it off_.) All comes out in the wash, old chap--all comes out in the wash, I assure you! (_Slaps him on the shoulder_.)
Well, then, I don't like it twice--do you hear! This is all your fault, Tempenny. You have got me into a pretty mess upon my word. My wife won't believe me, and I shall never hear the end of it.
(_To_ CHARLES SYLVESTER; _pointing to_ ROSALINE.) That girl is a perfect devil. She smacked my face just now when I was posing as a mandarin.
I was a mandarin when your wife came in--I thought it best--and this ex-mash of yours took advantage of me, and smacked my face.
(_To_ ROSALINE.) I tell you what it is,--I think you had better go. You had better be off--I can't have you here.
I quite agree. _I_ don't want her--she is more trouble than she is worth.
You are very rude to me, both of you. (_To_ CHARLES SYLVESTER.) Your manners have not improved with matrimony, my friend.
The point is that if you don't ask me properly, I shall do nothing of the kind. Now you've got it.
(_To_ REMBRANDT TEMPENNY _angrily_.) What the devil do you mean by bringing such a firebrand here?
Now don't lose your temper again. (_To_ ROSALINE.) Will you go?
That settles it. (_The two men look at each other helplessly_.)
If you please, sir, there is a gentleman downstairs who wants to see Mr. Tempenny.
I'm out. Go and tell him so. It only wanted this to complete my happiness. I won't see him, do you hear?
If you please the gentleman said he must see you, but if you was engaged, he'd wait.
You won't get rid of old Schercl in a hurry, if he has advanced you any of the "ready."
Tell him I'm out. Then let him come up if he likes.
I am going to dissemble. I am going to be an Eastern potentate, and I am going to spoof the old boy. (_To_ SARAH ANN.) Menial, slope! (_To_ CHARLES SYLVESTER.) Help me.
This is the rummiest studio that ever I was in!
Yes, originality is what we pride ourselves on. (_He disguises himself as the Maharajah of Slamthedoor_.)
You must be very deferential. I think you had better salaam when you speak to me. Try it.
That's it, only more so. And mind, if he wants to see Susannah, you don't let him look at it. It's only just begun. How do I look?
Dear child! how pretty she talks! Where did you originally find such a treasure?
Ah, Mr. Sylvester, how do you do? Where is Mr. Tempenny? I hoped to see him.
He has been compelled to go out on most important business.
The business of you gentlemen is always "most important" excepting when it concerns them that find you the wherewithal. (_Aside_.) What a nice girl!
I don't think, my dear Schercl, that you have much cause to complain. You don't lose by us; now confess!

My dear sir, if I lost by you how do you think I should garry on my business? One must live. But you artists don't give us much chance. You are always bleeding us for what you call "a bit on aggount."
Your conversation is very interesting, but I wish to see Mr. Tempenny. He is not here, and if he is not coming I shall go. Allah Bismillah Remdazzlegefoo!
(_Aside to_ HENRICH SCHERCL.) He's swearing because Tempenny is out.
I wanted to buy some of his great works. The Maharajah of Battledore told me that he was one of your most favourite painters.
(_Aside to_ CHARLES SYLVESTER.) Let _me_ deal with this sportsman.
Yes, my dear young friend. Now oblige me by skipping.
Right you are. Allow me to introduce to your Highness, Mr. Schercl--Mr. Schercl, the Maharajah of Slamthedoor.
He's swearing again. (_Aloud_.) I am sorry your Royal Highness has been kept waiting. These artists are such gurious people. Your Highness broboses to buy bictures, yes?
I have built a new palace at Slamthedoor, and I must have, of course, some pictures for my galleries.

(_Aside to_ ROSALINE.) Go away, girl--go away! One deal at a time! (_Aloud_) May I make so bold as to enquire the size of the new palace, Oh glorious One? (_Salaams_.) (_Aside_.) I think that is right!
The size? It is no bigger than my other one--it is about four times as large as your Buckingham Palace.
Great heavens! And you will have a vast picture gallery, Oh Light of my Eyes!
Five--five picture galleries, and I desire to fill them. That is why I am looking up these artists. My cousin the Maharajah of Battledore has given me several introductions.
_Doesn't_ your Royal Highness want any slaves? Ye before whose radiance the sun pales and the stars grow dim--no slaves?
(_Aside to_ ROSALINE.) Go away--go away--go away. Oh, demmit, will you go away! (_Salaaming_.) Most Serene One--
Proceed. But be quick--I am impatient to be gone. Allah Bismillah, be quick!

What a temper he's got! (_Aloud_.) Be guided by your servant. I have your Royal Highness's interest at heart. (_Aside_.) Also my own. (_Aloud_.) These bainters are so queer--they do not understand business at all, at all. Nach, they know nothing about it--at least very few of them. The less you have to do with them directly the better for your Royal Highness. If your Royal Highness wishes to fill the picture galleries of your new palace I'll take on the job at contract. I'll save you sixty per cent, s'welp me!
That is very kind of you. Why should you do it?
Well, your Royal Highness, I was struck by your demeanour and to tell your Royal Highness the truth, except with the Brince of Westphalia I have never done any business with royal families before.
You do not advise me then to see this Mr. Tempenny, or the other painters whose names I have?
Certainly not, your Royal Highness. Let _me_ arrange everything. Here's my card--Heinrich Schercl, 41 Golden Square.
(_Aside to_ HENRICH SCHERCL). Look here, what am I to have for this.
(_Aside to_ ROSALINE). We will talk later--we will talk later. Don't bother me!
My dear Mr. Schercl, I am delighted to have met you. You are quite confident you can _fill_ my galleries?

With genuine works of art. (_Aside_.) Poor Gamboge died last week; I am sure he hasn't sold more than three pictures during the last ten years--I can get the lot cheap. Only there must be 200 at least. What with all the other stony devils I can lay hands on, I'll soon decorate the old josser's walls.
Well then, I shall wait no longer--there is no need now. I shall call upon you, and settle our business together. Good-bye, miss, for the present. This is your daughter, I suppose?
I congratulate you. She is worthy to be a Princess.
This man's a flyer! I thought he was a mild young mug, but he fairly takes the merry little bun!
Good day, sir. My time in London is short. If I cannot call upon you, I will ask you to come to me at Claridge's.
Charmed, your Royal Highness. I shall be entirely at your disposition.
(_Skipping with ecstasy_). Jampagne! Little girl, I will stand you jampagne to zelebrate the deal.
Good biz! (_Opens L.D. and calls_). Here Mary, Matilda, Susan, or whatever your name is, you're wanted.
And you are a very charming girl, that is a fact. (_Lighting a cigarette_). I think I must give you a sovereign, yes?
I don't mind if I do. (_Taking cigarette from his case_). A "sovereign?" What are you talking about? My commission on this is a tenner--and I'm cheap at that!
(_Giving her money_). Fetch me a bottle of jampagne, and bring two glasses, eh?
And look slippy. Go on, I'm parched. Mind, the _best_ champagne. (_To_ HENRICH SCHERCL.) Got a light?
Well, I was struck by your demeanour, and to tell your Royal Highness the truth I have never done business with such a nice gentleman as you before.
Ha, ha, ha! You are a sharp girl too! You are too good to go to India to be a slave. You could do better in London.
You shall have a slave of your own--a slave who would love you.
It sounds very well. In the meantime what about the tenner?
(_Taking out his notebook_). You shall have it. There! Will you give me a kiss for that, my Rosie, with your rosy-posy lips?
Not before the child! Put it down, my girl, that'll do--Come on, Heinrich of the Golden Square, come and pour out the fluid.

Very likely. (_Aside_.) This is the best day's sitting I've ever done. (_Aloud_.) Now this is what I call comfortable: a bottle of the boy, a cigarette, and a cosy chat. I am very glad to have met you.
That is really so. But mind you, an hour ago, I should not have let you do this.
I am so blessed we did not meet an hour ago.
It is true. An hour ago I was in love, but I have been treated very badly. Just now my heart is at the rebound.
Now you are making fun of me. I am not so simple as you think. Why, we have only just met.
But we can meet again. Besides, I am not going yet--I will stop and talk to you. You shall tell me all about your love-trouble, and I will gonsole you. Hark, what is that?
Then I will step into the next room. It would not look vell that I should be found trinking jampagne mid a pretty girl like you. When they are gone I will come back.
Mr. Sylvester is in there. Here, if you don't want to be seen, get into this cupboard.
Clean as a new pin. Come on if you mean it, there's no time to waste. Now or never?
(_Going into cupboard, gingerly_). I am certain it is not glean.
(ROSALINE _shuts the door and turns as_ MRS. SYLVESTER _re-enters with_ MRS. TEMPENNY).
I told you so! Here she is as bold as brass. Now what do you say to that?
If indeed my husband brought her here--if he has really assisted Mr. Sylvester to deceive you--
(_Scornfully_). "IF!" The creature does not deny it. Speak, girl.
"Good afternoon?" It isn't a "good afternoon" I want you to say. Speak, I tell you.
(_R.D. slowly opens a little_--_showing_ REMBRANDT TEMPENNY _and_ CHARLES SYLVESTER _listening_).
(_Aside to_ CHARLES SYLVESTER). Can you do it, do you think?
(_Bursting into tears_). I will never forgive him as long as I live.
And _I'll_ see him, if I don't go home for a week!
(_Enter_ REMBRANDT TEMPENNY _backwards, very disordered attire_--_his entrance to suggest that he has been flung in_. CHARLES SYLVESTER _follows_).
(_With affected fury_). If you did not bring this person here, sir, how did she come?
What is all this? Oh, good gracious, the men have been fighting!
I am talking about Mrs. Tempenny. I say you would lead the best of wives to suppose that I--I--introduced this creature into your room. (_Weeps_.)
And through you I may be falsely suspected by Adelaide. (_Weeps_.)
All this is very fine--but who _is_ the man who brought her here if you didn't? Answer that.
Yes, if neither of _you_ did it, who did? Where _is_ the man?
(_Throwing open cupboard triumphantly and disclosing_ SCHERCL _covered with paint_.) There!
(SUSAN _discovered dusting. As Curtain goes up bell is heard off_.)

Was that the bell again? It is not the sort of place I am used to, this--where the master's afraid to see half the people who calls for him. I only hopes my wages is right. They was precious particular about _my_ references when they took me. Was I sober, honest and industrious, and the Lord knows what? Wish I'd been equal particular about theirs. The master ain't remarkably industrious, that I do know, for he often don't paint nothing for a week at a time; and he frequently ain't sober. Whether or not he is honest I shall find out at the end of my month. (_Bell rings again_.) It _was_ the bell--I'd better go and see who it is.
Mr. Tempenny in? Nonsense. Then I'll wait till he is.
I tell you I mean to see him. Now let us have the truth, girl, where is he?
"Mr. Tempenny, sir?" Yes, ma'am, who else? Now, is he at home?
Then I'll just sit down here till he comes back. You may go in and tell him so.
I hope you don't think I tell stories, sir? If Mr. Tempenny's out how can I take him your message?
Now, you understand, Susan, I am out to everyone, and if a Mr. Schercl calls--(_seeing_ HENRICH SCHERCL--_aside_). Good gracious! (_Aloud_.) Beg him to wait till I return--I want to see him.
My dear friend, how glad I am--how very glad! (_Aside_.) This is the very devil! (_Aloud_.) All right, Susan, you can go.
I want a leedle talk with you, my friend, without delay.
I hope the master'll enjoy himself, I'm sure! I did _my_ best for him anyhow!

Mr. Tempenny, I am here to demand an exblanation, sir--an exblanation of your strange behaviour of yesterday. And there is something else, sir. I find you are not Mr. Tempenny at all, sir, you are an imposter.
He did take me for Tempenny R.A., Addison was right! (_Aloud_.) An imposter, Mr. Schercl?
Zertainly, sir. I took you for _the_ Mr. Tempenny--it was to _the_ Mr. Tempenny, I brobosed to give my commission. You 'ave cheated me, you fellow.

Now, now, take care! How was _I_ to know you took me for somebody else? You came to me, and you made me an offer, and I accepted it. How could I tell you thought I was another--I may say an _inferior_--Tempenny? I say how could I know you were making a mistake?
You knew it very well. I would not pay tree 'undred pounds to _you_! What do you think I am--a fool? You 'ave obtained an order from me under false pretences, do you hear. I say you 'ave robbed me.
Gently! gently! this is slander, old gentleman. It will cost you a good deal _more_ than three hundred pounds if you aren't more guarded in your remarks.
It will really. I shall owe it to myself to have you up for slander, and it would be a very good advertisement for me too.

A really excellent advertisement. And what a fool you'd look! Come, come, you don't suppose your other Tempenny would have done you a work of this size for three hundred, do you? Nor as good either? No, no! As to the affair of yesterday, my wife was very much to blame--I am very angry with her. You see she has such curious ideas, and when she found you hidden in a cupboard with a paint-pot upset over you she thought it strange. It _wasn't_ strange, of course--(_airily_) most natural thing in the world, but she couldn't see it.
I felt very hurt to be so misunderstood. The only person who abbeared to have any zympathy for me was your model--the Miss Rosaline.
Nice girl! charming girl, isn't she? Full of feeling, and--I say, Schercl, you've made a conquest there, and no error.

Well, you have, you know! She made an awful scene after you left--said you were the only man she ever saw look dignified with a pot of paint upset over him. It is a pity in one way she _is_ so taken with you--I feel for her.
Vat rot you talk. Why should you feel for her?

Because you meant nothing by your attentions, Schercl, and the poor girl doesn't know that. She is thinking about you--not to put too fine a point upon it, she has fallen in love with you; and what do _you_ care?--you laugh!
No, I do not laff--I have a 'eart, have I not? I have the emotions and sensibilities.
You have, you have. But you do not realise how serious an impression you have made.
Well, now about Susannah. You can do it as well as your namesake. Yes?
"Zuperbly!" But I do not see it, and to me you never abbear to paint.
My dear friend, how can you doubt the success of the picture after you have seen the model who is sitting for it? Fair--beautiful form--exquisite arms--er--
Yes, yes, yes. So Miss Rosaline sits for your Susannah, eh?
Won't it be worth the three hundred--won't it be a dream.
I will come in one morning when you are at work! Yes, I am satisfied with the gontract--I say no more. I will come in when she is sitting.

No, you don't, my boy--oh no, you don't! The picture is what you get for your money--the real, living, breathing woman ain't included. Not much! Oh, no, Schercl, you old rogue--only the picture, sonny, no more. Ha, ha, ha!
You misunderstood me quite--I had no idea but of my business. I do not think of other things. Er--when will the picture be done, Tempenny, I would like it soon?
But according to our contract, it should be done in a week's time. If you disappoint me, my friend, we shall fall out again.

It strikes me you'll be precious lucky if you get it at all. The infernal "contract" is the bane of my life. (_Aloud_.) All right, Schercl, I will push on with it--I want the other two hundred, you know. I shan't delay for my own sake. (_Enter_ CHARLES SYLVESTER _L_.) Hallo, Charlie, how d'ye do. How are things at home?
I see another of yesterday's gulprits. However I have forgiven you.
That's all right. (_Aside to_ REMBRANDT TEMPENNY:) Rosaline's downstairs--wanting to see you. Where is your wife?
Out. (_To_ HENRICH SCHERCL.) That poor girl has followed you here. Perhaps out of pity you ought to go down to her and say a kind word.
Miss Rosaline--she is here? Well, I never! Yes, I will go down and speak to her. Where is she?
Damn it, in the drawing-room! Look here, Schercl, you can't go till _she_ does. If my wife comes in and finds her, she is your affair. Don't leave her for Heaven's sake.
Good morning, gentlemen. Oh, Mr. Schercl! What a pleasure--how _do_ you do?
I am very well, I thank you. And you?--I need not ask, you look most beautiful.
(_Aside to_ CHARLES SYLVESTER.) Why is Tempenny so afraid his wife should see her? You too--why are _you_ so afraid? Is she not of a good character, this Miss Rosaline?
(_Aside to_ HENRICH SCHERCL.) The girl is a paragon. They are jealous of her, that's all. She is too good-looking for 'em.

I think we'll leave you, old man. Rosaline, Mr. Schercl, has something to say to you--we shall be in the way. (_Aside to_ CHARLES SYLVESTER.) Come on, old chap--I wouldn't risk being found in the room again with the girl for a monkey.
Yes, I have some business to discuss with Mr. Tempenny. If you will excuse us--

(_Aside to_ HENRICH SCHERCL.) Take her away soon, there's a trump, or there will be another row. I give you five minutes to get her out of the house, Take her to breakfast--or--or--wherever you like, only hurry! (_Exit L._)
How funny to be left alone like this, isn't it, I really called to know when Mr. Tempenny proposed to continue the sittings. Do you know?
No, I have no idea. But I am very glad you called--our conversation yesterday was so inderrupted.
Yes, and we were getting on so nicely too, weren't we? Do you like my new hat? I bought it out of the tenner you gave me. What do you think of the bow--isn't it a duck?
You do not sit to Mr. Tempenny in a hat, I think.
In a--? Oh no, not in--. The subject is classical.
But now it is _you_ who sighs. Aren't _you_ happy?
If I was to tell you, you would call me "sentimental old fool."
Not _old_. Never a _fool_. (_With sudden persuasiveness_.) _Tell_ me!
I mean you go to him every day, and your zociety is very fascinating. That is all.
Of course, if you were Mr. Tempenny, you would see more of me. I should have said you would see me "_oftener_."
The little that I _have_ seen has made a great impression on me, Rosie--I shall never forget your face.
You are a model of perfection. I zympathise with you.
I assure you I think of you the more. Nevertheless I do not like the idea.
I have got used to it. And besides I am fortunately of a warm temperament. The wind is tempered to the shorn lamb.
I have not ever in my life seen a young lady who did make me feel for her the strange attraction that I feel for you, Rosie. I am jealous of this Mr. Tempenny.
Jealous! Do you mean you are in love with me? (_Aside_.) Oh, my goodness, what a joke!
And if I did, would you laugh at me? Supposing I was to say to you--"Rosie, I would like to marry you," what would you answer?
Say it, and see. (_Aside_.) He's in earnest. I do believe.
I am a very rich man. I could give you lots of such hats, and jewellery, and a big house.
You would not doubt my sincerity then. Now, you may think--
No, no, I do believe you. Do you care for me a little, Rosie?
Perhaps I do--a little. No, you are making game of me! (_Turns up_.)
I am not--I am not! I love you desperately. Rosie, will you be my wife. Say "yes" my darling.
You will not sit to Mr. Tempenny any more? It is not fit, now that you are to be Mrs. Schercl, that you should earn your living in such a way.
He will be very disappointed. He can't finish "Susannah" without me, and if he don't finish it, he won't get the two hundred pounds.
(_Enter_ MRS. SYLVESTER _and_ MRS. TEMPENNY. _L. dressed for walking_.)
Ah, my friend Tempenny's wife. And Mrs. Sylvester--how do you do?
By what right, sir, do you bring this person again--and into my private house.
I will, my treasure. (_To_ MRS. TEMPENNY.) I must trouble you, my good madam, to speak in terms of more respect of a lady who will shortly be my wife.
Let me introduce you: Mrs. Tempenny, Mrs. Sylvester--the future Mrs. Heinrich Schercl.
(_The two women gush up to her and shake her hands_.)
Why on earth didn't you tell me? They are engaged--I might have offended him for life!
How stupid you were! They are going to be married. Why, you might never have got an order from him again!
Dear, dear, dear, but my very good friend, if this lady is going to be your wife, how about "Susannah?"
Forgive me, "Susannah" cannot be. I release you from the contract.
Tidings of joy! (_Aloud_.) But--but--this is very hard on me.
I release you, and I pay you just the same.
But she has had the money for a dozen sittings.
If you please, sir, there's a hofficer of the law downstairs and he wants Mr. Tempenny or forty pun', sixteen shillings and ninepence.
I pay--and I gif you the balance by a jeque.
Pay--you pay? But the work of my life unfinished.--What money can compensate for that?
